titlestmt.titleproper: Connecticut Lesbian and Gay PRIDE Festival Collection GLTBQ.2013.02

publicationstmt.publisher: GLBTQ Archives, Central Connecticut State University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-04-19T14:49-0400

did.unittitle: Connecticut Lesbian and Gay PRIDE Festival Collection

repository.corpname: GLBTQ Archives, Central Connecticut State University

did.abstract: The first Hartford, Connecticut Lesbian and Gay PRIDE Festival took place on the lawn of Hartford’s Old State House June 26, 1982, from noon to three in the afternoon. Each of the eight organizers invited several friends, hoping that it would help boost the turn out. To their surprise, between 200 and 250 people showed up. By 2011, the festival had grown to accommodate well over 10,000 people. The day-long festival eventually adopted a format that began with a rally, then a march to the festival grounds. For many years, the rally began at the State Capitol, with the festival being held at Bushnell Park. The festivals were political, celebratory, and helped to foster communication between the different groups within the gay community. In addition to political speakers, another component of the early festivals included performances.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Oral history interviews of Carol Gale, Richard Stillson and Carolyn Gabel-Brett are available within the History 301 Oral History Project (GLTBQ2013.03) Collection of the GLTBQ Archives. Carol Gale's interview, specifically referencing the beginning of the PRIDE festivals, can be accessed within the Digital Collections of the GLTBQ Archives of the Elihu Burritt Library at Central Connecticut State University.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The first Hartford, Connecticut Lesbian and Gay PRIDE Festival took place on the lawn of Hartford’s Old State House June 26, 1982, from noon to three in the afternoon. It was organized by eight members of a group called the Greater Hartford Lesbian and Gay Task Force. No march was planned, but tickets were sold for seats on a bus to the New York’s Christopher Street Liberation Day Parade the next day. Part of the festival included a special showing of lesbian and gay films at Trinity College’s Cinestudio. Each of the eight organizers invited several friends, hoping that it would help boost the turn out. To their surprise, between 200 and 250 people showed up. By 2011, the festival had grown to accommodate well over 10,000 people.

In 1984, in order to separate the activities of organizing the festival from other political activities, the Connecticut Lesbian and Gay Pride Festival (CLGPF) was formed. The previous group eventually grew into the Connecticut Coalition for Lesbian and Gay Civil Rights, now the Connecticut Coalition for Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Civil Rights.

The Connecticut PRIDE Committee also worked to produce the festivals. According to the 1997 By Laws of the Connecticut PRIDE Committee, PRIDE stands for: P(eople) R(especting) I(ndividual) D(iversity) E(veryday). Eventually, the name of the organization producing the festival became the Connecticut PRIDE Hartford Rally and Festival, Inc.

The day-long festival itself adopted a format that began with a rally, then a march to the festival grounds. For many years, the rally began at the State Capitol, with the festival being held at Bushnell Park. This changed in 2012, when the organizers decided to cancel the festival due to the increase in cost. Information on the details of this decision is in a letter that was published on the producer’s website. It is now part of the collection.

The festivals were political, celebratory, and helped to foster communication between the different groups within the gay community. In addition to political speakers, another component of the early festivals included performances. One volunteer performance troupe calling themselves the “Signsations” wore a black sash with the name written in silver glitter. As the festival grew in size, commercial interests also grew. Sponsorships and vendors helped to pay for the increase in the costs of the event. Evidence of this can be seen within the realia contained in the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into four series: Programs and notes, Articles on festivals, Photographs and other graphic materials, and Realia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The collection contains programs, flyers, articles and realia relating to the festivals over the years, with the bulk of the material dating from 1982 through 2000. In addition, information regarding the LGBT State Employees Association and their fight to win “State Pride” are located in the collection.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Cite as: Connecticut Lesbian and Gay PRIDE Festival Collection, (GLBTQ Archives 2013.02), Elihu Burrit Library, Central Connecticut State University, New Britain.
